title: "How I use my bills to MAKE extra money" - Single mum reveals secret to earning £1,200 for 'free'
text:
Paula says her unsteady income has forced her to think outside of the box Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Inflation has jumped to 1.8% - its highest rate for two and a half years - and experts predict it will hit 2.7% by the end of the year - hitting households and families the hardest. 
With the prices of food, fuel and bills likely to rise, it’s a good time to start thinking about how you can beat the hikes by spending wiser and getting your finances into ship shape. 
There are obvious things like switching provider for energy , insurance, broadband , mobile phones and credit cards to ensure you aren't paying over the odds on boring bills. Read More How to save thousands of pounds on your bills with Martin Lewis 
But there are also other ways to help make your cash go further as one single mum has found. 
Paula Hancock is very canny with her cash. She shops around for the best deals before buying anything - and has even worked out a way to get paid to spend - which has earned her £1,200 so far. 
Paula, 40, who is mum to Madison, 13, and Jaxon, 5, says: "I’m really good with money, you need to be when you have kids and I work for myself so I don’t earn a set salary each month so need to be cautious. 
"I love to save money and get a buzz out of researching items before buying them both on the high street and online to ensure I’ve found the best price. I’ve now taken an extra step and signed up to Topcashback , a website where I can earn money when doing my shopping.” Read More How Lorna feeds her entire family for just £16.60 a week - and it's an awful lot easier than you might think 
Paula from Manchester says she was very sceptical when she first came across the site in 2015. "I thought it was a con at first but it didn't cost me anything to sign up so I thought I’d give it a go. 
"I kept forgetting to use it in the early days but then I installed a widget on my computer so whenever I’m shopping it lets me know if I can get cashback from retailers I’m using. 
"I don’t buy anything extra I just do my everyday shopping via the site from groceries to sorting out my home and car insurance when they come up for renewal and buying things like a takeaway pizza for the kids and holidays. 
"I’m impressed by the amount of cashback I have earned simply from doing my usual shopping. I usually save the cash up towards Christmas and turn a chunk of it into Amazon.co.uk vouchers because you get an extra 5% bonus if you do that. 
"It means I can really treat the kids. I've bought Jaxon an iPad mini and put £400 towards A MacBook for Madison." 
Paula keeps a slush fund in her cashback account in case of emergency. "I can also get the cash paid into my bank or PayPal account if and when I need it. I like having a bit of a financial safety net. 
“I am trying to teach the children good money management. We all have savings accounts. They both have accounts that were set up when they were born and they can’t touch them until they reach 17. Read More Junior ISA or child trust fund? How best to save for your children 
”Madison also has her own bank account and her monthly allowance goes into that. I’m trying to teach her that you can’t have everything at once and need to save up for some things. She’s really good and does save up for things, putting birthday and Christmas money in there too. 
“I've now got my mum earning cashback too, she’s just cashed in her first £39 and was really chuffed. I’d say people need to find the right cashback site for them. To work out where they do the bulk of their shopping and find a site that has those shops signed up. 
“But it is worth it over time. For just one extra simple step you can buy things at the best price and make some extra cash too.” 
Topcashback say members earn an average £325 per year with an average rate of 7.5% across retailers. 
Natasha Rachel Smith, Consumer Affairs Editor for Topcashback.co.uk , says: "It is increasingly important that consumers carefully control what they are spending. 
"This doesn't mean cutting back, but instead spending smartly and making the money do the hard work. Looking for discounts and bringing down the price of products with cashback can almost compensate for inflation.” Top tips to beat inflation 
Make sure you use all of your workplace benefits - from free coffee to healthcare and gym memberships. 
Think about buying big ticket items now - the price of most goods is set to rise with the fall in value of sterling. 
Enure you are on the best deals for all your household bills. 
If you have a surplus with your energy supplier once you've paid your winter bill, ask for a refund.
